citeinfo.origin: Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO)
citeinfo.title: PISCO: Intertidal: bionic mussel temperature data: Seal Rock, Oregon, USA (SRKX00)
citeinfo.othercit: Contact info for data set originator: Menge, Bruce Address:Oregon State University Corvallis, Oregon 97331 USA Email address:mengeb@science.oregonstate.edu Contact info for data set originator: Chan, Francis Address:Oregon State University Corvallis, Oregon 97331 USA Email address:chanft@science.oregonstate.edu

descript.abstract: This metadata record describes a mix of intertidal seawater and air temperature data collected at Seal Rock, Oregon, USA by PISCO. Measurements were collected using micro-T Temperature Logger (NexSens DS1921G) beginning 2007-04-16. Bionic mussel temperature loggers are contained within an artificial mussel in the middle of the mussel bed. There are typically two replicates with two loggers within each replicate. These are distinguished in the file name as follows: R11 - replicate 1, 1st logger; R12 - replicate 1, 2nd logger; R21 - replicate 2, 1st logger; R22 - replicate 2, 2nd logger. Temperature is recorded at 60.0 minute intervals.
descript.purpose: These data were collected by PISCO to understand the physical processes of the inner continental shelf and their potential effects on marine ecology.

timeperd.current: as it was at time of compilation

spdom.descgeog: Seal Rock, Oregon: SRKX00: The Seal Rock site is approximately 10 miles south of Newport on HWY 101 in the town of Seal Rock. This site is approximately 300 yards west of the parking area. Altitude is height above Mean Lower Low Water (MLLW). This is a bionic mussel temperature logger in the middle of the mussel bed.

theme.themekey: EARTH SCIENCE : Oceans : Ocean Temperature : Water Temperature

idinfo.useconst: Please cite PISCO in all publications containing these data. The citation should take the form: "This study utilized data collected by the Partnership for Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans: a long-term ecological consortium funded by the David and Lucile Packard Foundation and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation." Please send copies of any published manuscript based on these data to the PISCO Program Coordinator (http://piscoweb.org/who/coordinators). Users of these data are encouraged to contact the Principal Investigators. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on PISCO data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original PISCO investigators.Extensive efforts are made to ensure that online data are accurate and up to date, but the authors and PISCO will not take responsibility for any errors that may exist in data provided online. Furthermore, the user assumes all responsibility for errors in analysis or judgment resulting from use of the data.

attr.attrdef: calendar date of each temperature measurement record
Greenwich Mean Time of each temperature measurement record

Time of each temperature measurement record, expressed as decimal days since 12 a.m. Jan. 1 of the year measurement was made. For example, 12 noon GMT on Jan. 2 is represented by yearday 1.5, NOT yearday 2.5.
data flag used to qualify data as bad, questionable, etc.

attrdomv.udom: Data for each column of the data file are flagged with a single alpha-numeric code such that the first digit holds the first data column flag, the second digit holds the second data column flag, etc. Possible flags are 0-9, A-Z, a-z; however flag definitions are currently as follows: 0 - No known bad data; 1 - Known bad data: instrument malfunction/failure, loss of memory, loss of power, bio-fouling, electronic malfunction; 2 - Suspicious data (looks bad, but no known cause); 9 - Missing data (data column has a missing value code as defined in the metadata) [0-9A-Za-z][0-9A-Za-z][0-9A-Za-z][0-9A-Za-z]PISCO/NMS Physical Oceanography Team accepted flagging conventions
